D7FA5BF31CD8467ABA55FCAE9385E319.description: Recognize basic guidelines for adding inflectional endings.

DB78495E503542728BDF2C2235140EFE.description: Recognize and spell contractions in writing.

425C06A8C0494C888928CF311521078E.description: Use a variety of tools to spell or confirm the spelling of words.

AFD80BA8830E4E2DAD853AF048F2568A.description: Apply a variety of spelling strategies to enhance written expression.

0F285DA5DBB7444AB73090C67793F82D.description: Identify words that are not spelled in predictable ways.

81DC88815CC64C3CBC1A18BA9A312512.description: Spell a variety of prefixes and suffixes accurately in words.

7A41D5565C0C4B67806045E3A8B115EC.description: Add only an apostrophe to show ownership if a noun is plural and already ends in an < s >.

4EA4666B742F4F3784BC143590EA7733.description: Add an apostrophe and an < s > to nouns to show ownership.

0C1BF92C12BD4F718C2A60E48FD61401.description: Identify plural nouns that are spelled the same as or differently from their singular form.

1E11E4AF13F644F0BB6B579C96C43497.description: Apply knowledge of known words, word parts, and word patterns to spell unfamiliar words.

4D869737C670410EBB6DB789CA8A28DA.description: Identify spelling patterns within and across words.

20C02AF29C4940E184A86AB0131C2740.description: Recognize and use prepositions in sentences to show time and place.

982DBBB8CDD64BFA987AA53D713A77C8.description: Differentiate between possessive nouns, possessive adjectives, and possessive pronouns.

BA0F61F06C4843E8BF1ECC2B3290667B.description: Identify subject-verb agreement in a variety of sentences.

D831557D4C77435AA9222FF98E8DBDA1.description: Examine conjunctions in a variety of sentences.

0E4FD9E9BB1E4D2DB3DCD04AE675C9D3.description: Identify the predicate of a variety of sentences.

F81B9A5BC55244E290615D4700610B55.description: Distinguish between a variety of sentence types.

5AD022FA6E234B91B366F0907FAA1E21.description: Insert commas to indicate a pause between parts of sentences or to separate items in a list.

D62E307B4A0D4AFFB73777669EC9F12A.description: Capitalize words appropriately in different contexts.

223E4432EFBE4A4AA2593A5C2618C574.description: Basic guidelines for spelling transferred to writing new text can increase accuracy.

254C06D9A4394CB79D1A9449724959C8.description: A variety of spelling strategies and tools can be used to enhance written expression.

E543A616AE0F486EB3FA85749B64EA87.description: Correct spelling can be supported by applying knowledge of word patterns and parts.

641F7B232C4C40D99A07834F47FC308F.description: Grammar can provide a consistent structure for the building of sentences.

6B1D8130CEC5476EA13E77118AB7554D.description: Capitalization and punctuation can enhance written expression.

CCD1BC11C17D4B7A851306252B175698.description: The basic guidelines for adding inflectional endings consist of dropping the < e > and adding < ing > and doubling the letter before adding < ing > or < ed >.

CCD67AFBF6F34FE8B0B58DDA1A2CB651.description: An inflectional ending is a suffix added to a base that indicates tense, plurality, possession and comparison.

9C95E1EF81B8458786265CD60AE05385.description: An abbreviation is the shortened form of a word or words (e.g., Rd., St., AB).

44A6172EDDE54568B24B9A4C2210C7F2.description: Abbreviations include titles, days of the week, time, measurements and addresses.

5D1838BD5B9944B9815BF6620C9B8295.description: Digital or non-digital tools can be used to help spell words correctly.

EA9EAD6162984C8B9457A7E74C07B0A6.description: Spelling strategies can be used to spell words accurately, including articulating, visualizing, transferring prior knowledge and trial and error.

0B5C8CFEF23446E7AFEC72063BB378F2.description: Some words are not spelled in predictable ways.

45AEA9A2941845C590BADC2E0CB7F6D2.description: Prefixes and suffixes are spelled consistently in words.

563E64861974489AA9FF93CBD0B72D47.description: If a noun is plural and already ends in an < s >, only an apostrophe and not an < s > is added to show ownership.

D74721F9B76D461D954FB3C4C0E8C614.description: Adding an apostrophe and < s > can be used to show ownership or possession.

0CBBC7F9FDA34911BC9B37F5F621DC35.description: Some plural nouns may be spelled the same as or differently from their singular form (e.g., moose-moose, person-people).

8343A68F9FCF4D57988F4447FB3A38ED.description: Spelling patterns include nouns ending in < y >: change < y > to < I > and add < es > (e.g., pony � ponies) and nouns ending in < f > or < fe >: change < f > or < fe > to < v > and add < es > (e.g., leaf � leaves).

734D15D8043F4AD1A9ABF5F453C364C6.description: Some words can be used with other words to show time or place (prepositions) (e.g., under, with, before, after).

A813499DE9C5411CBF19DEFF6E125310.description: Words can tell who or what owns a noun (possessive), and include possessive nouns (� s), possessive adjectives (e.g., my, your, his, her, its, our, their) and possessive pronouns (e.g., mine, yours, his, hers, ours, theirs).

8F40FE91AA934B6AA2613DFB9B671837.description: Subject-verb agreement means that the subject and the verb must agree, with both being either singular or plural.

83F48BAE9CD34E4395493188DA19FA79.description: An adverb is a word that describes a verb.

F75CAC500D0048F7BFD0CB517786B7A6.description: An adjective is a word that describes a noun.

E15CCDD8E6E24E2689043AD149492427.description: Words can be used to connect phrases and sentences (conjunctions) (e.g., and, but, or, so, for).

7FF86FCDA38F411FACFBB24D120CCDD9.description: The predicate of a sentence is what the subject does.

F7888CF0DB9A410CA23A39DB2FFFDBD3.description: The subject of a sentence is who or what the sentence is about.

32C2D70D0877408EB189B3FF1F438E74.description: A sentence has two main parts, a subject and a predicate.

53651AF8A8CC42DFB91712ADBD4DD925.description: A sentence can command someone to do or not to do something (imperative).

1AD9DD573E2C4E6E875D99086D1E9890.description: Adding an apostrophe and < s > can be used to show ownership or possession.

1E7462697C484ED5B22BB2253A29F9DB.description: Quotation marks identify the words of a speaker or bring attention to a word that is used in a special way.

4C4EBC879B974399B7A0A4503761E674.description: A comma indicates a pause between parts of a sentence or separates items in a list.

251919E1C66740C0A9898928E33FBB75.description: Punctuation includes commas quotation marks and apostrophes in contractions and possessives.

8445DE6C88994457B1687E41C890D607.description: Students investigate and demonstrate how conventions support written communication.

D0977712DE8446E1B437C82D1DD3C454.description: Conventions: Understanding grammar, spelling, and punctuation makes it easier to communicate clearly, to organize thinking, and to use language for desired effects.

CEB1E4EA9C684FC3BE54565BB71293C2.description: Use cursive handwriting to write some texts with appropriate letter formation, size, proportion, and slant.

02187C28A0CF4FE5A55F03955B13BE68.description: Demonstrate writing fluency using at least one method or tool.

3DDF8F077221412180269F459C3DEFFF.description: List sources of information used to inform research.

5663F30A6000419BB66CCB4873E30DB6.description: Use research to create written text that is appropriate for an audience.

F784CF39E9E74837B24A28CDC14BC709.description: Organize, categorize, or sequence information using a variety of methods or tools.

011D5EEC59D94A83B133DE1806875F8E.description: Access information from a variety of sources to answer questions or expand knowledge.

B74CDF5CE845469989945B479C3763E6.description: Persevere through challenges that may arise in the creative expression of ideas.

F23B705898C241D1B2A5756D5A5E886D.description: Select from a variety of presentation forms or text features to enhance and share selections of creative writing.

F30F33219987429DB4F6FAF8D7049CE3.description: Create thoughtful conclusions to tie up events or leave readers wondering.

C03F409BC4E8408FB8353F5F8763A1CE.description: Use punctuation to generate effects in creative expression.

95CD24CE6D464CF5B41502638509B87E.description: Include dialogue to add variety to texts.

908B905904684EECA86B04C9BDAA2AC0.description: Include a variety of carefully selected words and sensory detail to add interest and keep audiences engaged.

69CB9EEFA2E34938A3FB0C430035025C.description: Create beginnings that catch the audience � s attention by experimenting with ideas and word choice.

AAD8156422F44DA68A29E260BB6FC39B.description: Select from a variety of text forms or structures to express personal thoughts or feelings.

8A101111EE714B35ACF60FB399900425.description: Create written texts that draw upon a variety of sources of inspiration.

4DEC3855F1FD4316A54BC324F60055BC.description: Examine how other writers use words, sensory detail, and figurative language for creative expression of thoughts and emotions.

A8E731EB71C04B9FBD56B6E79D45F398.description: Examine how relationships between audience, purpose, and text form can influence creative expression.

87F880B53A044FE5A684A0EBCEC78756.description: Select a variety of texts to be shared according to their purpose.

51519EC16D244EF6B5BD6F9193A02A21.description: Read written texts aloud to check for writing fluency.

27CB6E8A51824C089F3D094E26D8BEE2.description: Edit writing for spelling, punctuation, and grammar.

7C0470172FAA44B29800FF9532E81072.description: Revise written texts for accuracy, clarity, or appeal by adding, removing, or changing words or sentences.

2C0970A39E0C427EB73304E14FF97DCB.description: Sequence sections of writing in a logical order.

2199672484D64FE4A821C76B31CDC35F.description: Include a range of sentence beginnings and types to vary and add interest to writing.

9C2C985390144AFA85C556BAF4B76730.description: Create drafts of writing that maintain audience interest by focusing the number of ideas in sentences and limiting repetitions.

F9B331233D8C4B9296694161DD2E4F70.description: Use organizational processes, methods, or tools to support the creation of written texts.

E1A82AE28F2E439EACC8A99A52152673.description: Create written texts using a variety of forms and structures.

1F0D6CAE523446998B2DF8A4566C4D78.description: Create written texts for a variety of audiences and purposes.

75FF4718A85245688FEAA39922DCF82B.description: Practice using digital or non-digital methods or tools can support writing fluency.

24181B3FA93D447A9B2E9BD5318808CC.description: Research processes can support accessing and logically organizing information.

B135736410DC4FEA8DE76B6BAE646C66.description: Creative expression can channel imaginative thought and emotion into a variety of texts.

3B9A56722F63485690292A7FDCF11204.description: Writing can capture ideas, memories, investigations, and stories.

2BA3F7F3A61349C8BB3D90CBA2454BE1.description: Basic keyboarding involves finger reaches, keystroking and key recognition.

936121A6429741D7ABEDD10A7ABFBC15.description: Cursive handwriting involves letter formation, size, proportion and slant.

04DD530635D94251B08651CDC3D7C2EC.description: Written messages can be created using a variety of digital or non-digital methods or tools, such as printing, keyboarding and cursive handwriting.

034206065B4642D4B49478A5711EE2B1.description: The information and ideas of others need to be listed (cited) in research writing.

0F539801A3254C7D96B8DC51BF5A7916.description: Research findings can be shared in a variety of digital or non-digital forms, including reports, presentations and visual representations.

B74FF71667B7491CA08C4C2D820E7252.description: Organizational tools, such as graphic organizers, can help plan and write about factual information.

9217A8936C1845459459EE473D79D79E.description: Information can be categorized or sequenced to enhance organization.

F8D97AB3DB4E40B8831D6942BB3877E2.description: Information can be accessed, stored, and shared in a variety of digital and non-digital ways.

92B2B4F9B225423B8C8CFBCD74734A64.description: Questioning can help focus research topics and processes.

F0746B1771914A0FBFDAAD91743D2FE3.description: Dialogue can be used to add variety to written texts.

2A6F3C92AB474E499A2A2DEBB66E4937.description: Words selected to enhance written texts include sensory details, synonyms, antonyms and specific words or phrases.

81BED1C9CCBE475DB41CDE3B983B4006.description: In creative writing, word choice includes interesting details that keep audiences engaged.

227BBEF67AB44D1C94019592EB52DD7E.description: The author � s voice or style helps a reader or an audience picture or feel what a writer is describing.

69A43B6C5F624DC2BB297C4B1A94040B.description: Creative ideas for expression can be inspired by a variety of sources, including personal experiences, background knowledge, imagination and experiences with text.

F09CEE37C5F3434C8D75440345AB9CDD.description: Writing is a craft that involves personal expression of ideas through organization, word choice and presentation.

5DF0282A33BA4D2DA4391B3B02132DCD.description: Creative thinking involves considering audience and purpose, brainstorming to expand ideas, seeking out information to help transform ideas into representations and persevering through challenges that may arise.

A0FA10BA4F994A1C886F6C15051FB398.description: Sharing can involve selecting a variety of text features to enhance written messages.

78EC1137F61047BAB799EA65C4F1EDE5.description: Fluent writing sounds like speaking when read aloud.

5CC6D6637DD7499B8E043BCBF7A229B9.description: Revising includes adding or removing words or sentences to enhance writing clarity, accuracy, or appeal.

09AD04EB0B7D4944B0C408A3AD675A26.description: Three to five sentences that add detail or description to ideas or information can be combined to construct a paragraph.

25D2E372BB304E99A24993BAAF182C90.description: Writers generally avoid repetitions and run-on sentences.

CC9048944AC048E184E8E9177DB4FABE.description: Run-on sentences make reading difficult, as the reader often cannot tell where to pause or stop.

CE0BA0F1506B4BE090067A631605B49D.description: Interest can be created by varying sentence beginnings.

C81190C744914F60A8F209AA957E2AA3.description: Drafting involves organizing words on paper during the writing process.

2F50961A1A94441CAC432812C8161076.description: Methods and tools that can support planning include graphic organizers and sketching.

D1280743FAD746FA9F0E9A93E0BD2B76.description: Planning includes consideration of audience, purpose, form and idea generation.

CA3906A2614E4863A4337FFF2E6999A5.description: Writing processes used to organize and share messages include planning, drafting, revising, editing and sharing.

34C813A48DCE4022AEBB418074706F5D.description: Students investigate writing and research processes that support informed written expression.

F6F9843C67C4450291B3C36CDC3BE0EA.description: Writing: Ideas and information can be articulated accurately and imaginatively through the use of writing processes and an understanding of the author�s craft.

24023DA2C139496B878CF73D6F504873.description: Identify self-monitoring skills that are personally effective in supporting reading comprehension.

F2A1295A55364F7BBE485E4E1E35C468.description: Examine the location in texts where reading comprehension becomes challenging.

0CE2D378CC8146B981DAEE241688E0B1.description: Share important information from a text in a logical order using own words.

89FAA7BC1613449181B89C9B6C69B5B2.description: Order significant information from a text in a logical sequence.

8DABC529A6D3481898B34C6F0CC25FFD.description: Determine the most important information in a text.

4C910956E89649A880612CF1E69C4D43.description: Identify connections between the actions, feelings, or motives of a character and evidence in text.

B7502C22429549B091258A890068A630.description: Make inferences by combining background knowledge with information that is not explicitly stated within a text.

A3489BC5E14D444F9C8FE25637FF742D.description: Reflect on predictions to confirm or change understandings.

4AC0E6958CF4495AB23E80125918F5F4.description: Modify predictions based on new or additional information.

1692EDD1138E432FAB7303677F50880A.description: Identify information from texts that supports predictions.

0E33C04510F2498BA56D4B5AE600F657.description: Make predictions using background knowledge and information within a text.

8326BCD75CD949D1897314FDFFB02D82.description: Make connections between texts and ideas that relate to past, present, or future world events.

A4F396BB791F4B90B6F8FE86B57C6F56.description: Make connections between various aspects within or between texts.

1D97E9AE55094580B77B29B02771EFB2.description: Make connections between a text and personal feelings, experiences, or background knowledge.

723B50EACF87457EBF58BC55C0BD97C8.description: Independently read and demonstrate comprehension of texts that vary in length or complexity.

5FB3C5046E5F49E8A2DC25C95CE1477F.description: The reading comprehension process involves the strategies of monitoring understandings and assessing options if meaning lacks clarity.

6B1CFE96BBCB4D1D82376185FC660367.description: Comprehension is enhanced when information is summarized.

387F0986DAAA4752B2A370129C142E22.description: Comprehension can be enhanced by inferring meanings that are not stated explicitly in text.

D6173C5DFEB1497699E58C778A80FE9C.description: Comprehension involves predicting outcomes or events that reflect clues from texts.

BA267384CF584BF5BEEE3DB58238C483.description: Comprehension involves connecting relevant background knowledge and experiences with new information in text.

FDF594121A7B47E49CDC866CACC24876.description: Critical thinking can be applied to comprehend texts that vary in length or complexity.

C38079D32454472EB8006E3E8AA90078.description: Self-monitoring skills that can be used when facing challenges in comprehension include noticing where meaning breaks down, rereading, reading ahead, creating mental or visual images and asking and answering how, why, and what if questions.

03DD12BA02844FB4BBF5A9D1741EDB08.description: Summarizing information involves determining key ideas and specific details, logically ordering ideas and writing ideas in own words.

7A7B3028759F4D80883559133C445580.description: Inferencing can involve making connections, questioning, predicting and visualizing.

51963AC65599406182AC040DC0335809.description: Inferencing involves drawing conclusions based on known facts or evidence.

2AA6543A2D03449CAD75820A8BAA33DA.description: Predictions can be made by combining information from texts with background knowledge, personal experience and anticipation of logical outcomes or events.

48A58A2307634CEA8A7D91105D961179.description: Connections can be made between texts and ideas that relate to past, present, or future world events (text to world).

23E27CB0699F4DC99630C119D44280C2.description: Connections can be made prior to, during, or after reading a text.

55BB363E38D9477E898DD53EA31A73B3.description: Comprehension of longer, more complex texts is supported by increased reading practice.

D758D29AABA84A3A9445A3632168F827.description: Students analyze text and make connections to personal experiences to support meaning.

0601462A1BAA496EA993B9C500583765.description: Comprehension: Text comprehension is supported by applying varied strategies and processes and by considering both particular contexts and universal themes.

2C98309C2C4246DAB941A2B1C5D4120A.description: Read the 300 high-frequency words learned in grades 1 and 2 fluently in continuous text.

47A2D75CD7424683B90F13E6BE1650B8.description: Read a variety of text forms with fluency and expression.

357E0FB703084369956FAD624CC308D1.description: Read increasingly complex text with appropriate pace, word stress, phrasing, and pausing.

C19B9FC01EE2487FBF7E04F0051A6160.description: Demonstrate automaticity in reading complex words, phrases, and continuous text.

9F04F36322FE442BA8F32C604C188CA2.description: Fluent recognition of high-frequency words (the 300 learned in grades 1 and 2) supports effective and efficient reading comprehension.

125502737F1146FE9A3D99DA895D1FB5.description: Reading fluency involves accuracy, automaticity, and prosody to engage an audience or improve comprehension.

B7686BCA7E96479FBB377AE4273491A6.description: Comprehension is enhanced when high-frequency words are read in continuous text at an appropriate pace.

2EBE8226333C475DA52BB8D78EAE7E0D.description: Fluent reading includes accuracy, automaticity in word recognition and prosody (stress, expression, intonation, and pausing) in oral text reading.

CE70E304ED84446D825915F2EB717151.description: Fluency develops over time with practice.

12FB2A682FDD4EDF91A554FF67CCFC69.description: Students apply fluency strategies and develop reading comprehension.

7416CB4ABDF84E70A3F4A235BE4EFE9B.description: Fluency: Comprehension and literary appreciation are improved by the ability to read a range of texts accurately, automatically, and with expression.

75E707040FAF4023A0715A680E409CFC.description: Use phonetic strategies to decode complex words in continuous text.

05E8169FB63446708785D9127EEFB578.description: Recognize and apply a wide variety of long and short vowel sounds when decoding unknown multisyllabic words.

D5117521AAB94DE89C3610C2C4447941.description: Recognize and apply consonant letters that represent no sounds.

A8998441C5794E92B10C49A0FD16F80B.description: Recognize and apply less frequent consonant digraphs.

BE482A8C729E4ED1A5440D74619D8769.description: Recognize consonant clusters at the beginning and ending of a word.

4A4B45A08AD342B78B51D308EA668FE5.description: Phonics supports the reading and writing of texts.

009AC9C938D34BA7A855971D8CC4B4DB.description: Connections can be made between phonemes and graphemes, including consonant clusters and digraphs.

5D62F7D7744F42BCB5D0F5FF723CE8F3.description: Chunking is a phonetic strategy used to decode that breaks large words into small parts.

31F2FF27EE884F5DAB226F51C9B0FF20.description: Some consonant letters represent no sound (e.g., know, write).

9EE2BD6431814417A4F5A122B4F3F4B9.description: Consonant digraphs are two consonant letters that appear together and represent a single sound that is different from the sound of either letter (e.g., sh).

D3E678149FC04EBBA0EB0397311EDD43.description: Consonant clusters appear at the beginning and ending of words.

73E8878D202344C3AB0F1A97DD721ED7.description: Consonant clusters blend two or three consonant sounds.

25BC74B0AAFC468CA554E25A3FA8FB88.description: Students investigate how phonics connects to word formation and supports the processes of reading and writing.

8AE38208B8D14D05A4D0AB4EC9207C1B.description: Phonics: Foundational literacy is supported by understanding relationships between sounds in oral language and the letters that represent them.

C834748D60D04109B4B4EA1E124715CD.description: Analyze frequently used compound words and their meanings.

670D019F752742C0936AD29159FDC947.description: Recognize and use suffixes to name a person that does something.

A7D51E90DBBF44558754E71877440190.description: Recognize and use suffixes to form adverbs that describe a specific manner, period of time, or order.

E647A461140D4F11A82094271E003E8A.description: Analyze bases and affixes for meaning.

F3AC2FAF3E254E05A51110E5A3CC01A9.description: Analyze and use synonyms, antonyms, homophones, homographs, and words with multiple meanings in a variety of texts.

A7F0A909C3054182A02C3CCDE70AFF3A.description: Recognize and use figurative language in oral and written communication.

A8E64BE6D84C4C508B1A964F7C13B770.description: Integrate knowledge of vocabulary across multiple literacy contexts.

8E21605CF1D54C82A2C6D5B87B7B312A.description: Engage with texts that include more sophisticated concepts and ideas expressed through expanded vocabulary.

01543FEBC83F4380B801FBB1B02B8BD6.description: Develop tier 3 vocabulary through content-area learning.

12072AC2CA094BBCBD7F806F41E5F0F9.description: Use tier 2 words in a variety of literacy contexts.

5D13B9D5BFAF4D44B38068AB0322E833.description: The study of words and how they are formed (morphology) can support development of vocabulary and enhance comprehension.

2E67617A8C14450FA5EE29379D5FB161.description: Vocabulary knowledge can be supported and developed through literacy interactions and experiences.

7A2795099CB9472BA01799BC2E71480D.description: Suffixes, including <er>, <or>, <ar>, and <ist>, are morphemes that change the meaning of words when added to the ending of a base.

8F8D0FBF74464FD290B3B259F391D296.description: Suffixes, including <ly>, are morphemes that form adverbs and change the meaning of words when added to the ending of a base.

4399AF604AB543879B4EB24E449295DA.description: Prefixes, including <re>, <un>, <in>, <dis>, <non>, <mis>, <mal>, <sub>, and <super>, are morphemes that change the meaning of words when added to the beginning of a base.

02E7215C06214BB8AEA041DC579F426C.description: An affix is a letter or group of letters that comes at the beginning (prefix) or ending (suffix) of a word and has a meaning of its own.

FE02C3A515CD40B5B064D348024D78D9.description: A base is a word or word part that has meaning and to which an affix can be added.

C9668C801F274977AEDF323A9C787E3C.description: A simile compares two unlike things using like or as.

11E858AD5708470FB72AC3BDF358378C.description: Hyperbole is when words or phrases are used to exaggerate meaning.

A559952145184B9288054D4D4030E72C.description: Imagery is when words or phrases describe ideas or things that can be experienced visually.

151A2B14A5AB415D8501365AC05FE55C.description: Figurative language includes imagery, hyperbole, simile.

AB17CF9CCA78413A9EB156B17D80D3A1.description: Language involves phrases with literal and figurative meanings that can be used to enhance communication.

ECE81890E73B41DB8EB044E95F8ED4DC.description: The meaning of a word can change when used in a different context.

141BBC106CF0409389E0B0384EDAD1C9.description: Speaking can be supported through relaxation, breathing and posture.

B3BC33CDD82C415ABC8C59144ADDCA35.description: Throughout history, languages developed orally before being written.

6B2BC550485D41FD9A4A2461E3C7051A.description: Students examine and apply listening and speaking skills, processes, or strategies in a variety of formal and informal interactions.

935033081CAB4103B79C28FF7A640D78.description: Oral Language: Listening and speaking form the foundation for literacy development and improve communication, collaboration, and respectful mutual understanding.

48AD1DC9CFAB4ED38875F678A8AADF5C.description: Examine poetic structures that contribute to creative expression of ideas.

456F2091E0B94EEDAF0864FF5BC36E97.description: Examine elements within a variety of fictional texts.

F4151A41647C46BB88B151BC884D89D6.description: Include a variety of text features to organize, clarify, or enhance personal messages.

5FC083866CF243638FFCF18430A1412C.description: Determine how the structure of texts can help organize the expression or understanding of ideas or information.

1D54ADD5A5534299A037ACDE61DF350E.description: Examine the structure of a variety of fiction and non-fiction texts.

9517A29E82C049AF81BAABAADC2F7766.description: Examine the form of a variety of fiction and non-fiction texts.

E67BDD8E3E1740688AB1611702D57C2B.description: Differentiate between fiction and non-fiction texts according to content.

A99D5CD723A6487BB71B4BE028319F80.description: Explain personal preferences for texts that provide enjoyment.

A978F60D3D4643398B9FA935C46577F7.description: Examine the purpose of a variety of texts.

F2FF2A34FFA64891999F53D85733B757.description: Poetry is a form of expression that encourages creativity and new ways of thinking about ideas and feelings.

F2DE0CD40BB049D7ADF196D2C888F9FC.description: Non-fiction texts have structures that support the sharing of factual information to explain or describe real people, places, things, or events.

B3CB10B10040461EBBA83F3F31E8B927.description: Fictional texts are often products of a text creators imagination and are not factual.

FDDF17CD236D4EE1B306086F9C9D66C2.description: Text features can provide information that is not in the main body of a text.

B232F68AB19A442F988D9E041E5D40F1.description: The purpose, form, or structure of texts can help organize the expression and understanding of ideas and information.

9A149BDB9AB3458FA35FDBD5773B3B4E.description: A limerick is a poem that consists of five lines with a rhyme scheme of AABBA.

9557B74942E149888A372C0E81B864D7.description: A haiku is a short Japanese poem of seventeen syllables (organized into three lines of five, seven, and five syllables) that traditionally emphasizes images from nature.

49642B49452147449C16611F23A2C47B.description: Poetic structures include haiku and limerick.

FE738742DFBA40A8894C765CA29EB0E0.description: Poetry includes words or phrases used in a non-literal way to create a desired effect (figurative language).

DBF3414DA9AE4F869F5C45E3F9E987D3.description: Non-fiction texts can have structures that include main idea or topic, supporting details, linear or cyclical sequencing and compare and contrast.

DA5863E96EB8436CAF696DDA9274379E.description: Content-area texts refer to texts from subjects such as science, social studies, and fine arts.

C71FEBDC8F6F4791889F2189AF4B98AD.description: Non-fiction texts include biographies, content-area texts, interactions with people and land.

8E1760A6E9B644B8A63D33AB77F92FAE.description: A narrator can be a character in a story or someone telling the story from the outside looking in.

AEB9A94125B841B0BBF36122759A5CDA.description: A circular plot is sequenced to end with characters returning to a similar situation to where they started.

331C808351FB4DF0955D6DE97605CD6F.description: A major character is central to the plot or problem in a story.

2606C9B26187488DACB02DAD7011E13C.description: Elements of fiction include major characters, setting and plot.

F5E8FA12AE7D463B86BB90D4824F0E41.description: Fictional texts can have structures that include books with chapters, collections of stories related to a single idea and circular plots.

560F4D92282047B6B01C7CA0CF5DE7CD.description: A mystery describes the solution of a crime or the unravelling of secrets.

940A602B6CA4402E8713974E504EE9BF.description: Historical fiction takes place in a setting of the past.

997C9283AAB949FB9643EE9799ABB3F8.description: Realistic fiction takes place in modern times and describes believable characters involved in plausible events.

3E6792EAB9FA45DB803EB0F752A59126.description: A myth is a traditional or legendary story usually concerning a courageous hero or heroine or an event.

20DF2A9DEF564016A0BC047475629499.description: Fictional texts can be categorized by sub-forms that include traditional literature, including myths, realistic fiction, historical fiction and mystery.

C36978E822864CF6B8C828B45D451E7B.description: Text features can be digital or non-digital, including images, tables of contents, maps and graphs.

B9A4A381CC2443A18490F8327AD8B4E0.description: Stories can be fiction or non-fiction and can follow a structure, including beginning, problem, events, solution and ending.

B888F712121042BCA940532A34CAD10C.description: Literary forms of fiction and non-fiction texts include drama, short stories and images.

5139319A9747429C8A11CB17929A1129.description: Non-fiction is a type of text that expresses information and facts.

4D89C8806E3649F7BF993EC3A11B0E9A.description: Fiction is a type of text that uses imagination to tell a story.

70A1221726E54E1CB7E78B854C521E74.description: Texts can be categorized according to their content and include fiction and non-fiction.

4BC61EFE509B4E4F85CE1C2DF703F8A3.description: The purpose of a text can be to inform and provide enjoyment.

97386DFDB9E64C0D9CFF54B1F11CD53F.description: A text is anything, digital or non-digital, that has meaning for the individual or group who creates or engages with it.

FB7396B5B8354892B182884F7771D133.description: Students relate the form and structure of texts to the communication of ideas and information.

A30F0EFCA1E14E43B0D2DC2C607D5837.description: Text Forms and Structures: Identifying and applying text forms and structures improves understanding of content, literary style, and our rich language traditions.
